results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is entitled ‘Daddy wouldn’t buy me a Bow-Bow’ and is credited to Tibor and Merna Koller. It is staged as a narrative film, following a teenage girl, presumably the couple’s daughter, visiting a kennel to buy a puppy and bringing it home.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Daddy wouldn’t buy me a Bow-Bow’ followed by ‘Produced by Tibor & Merna Koller 1968’
00:00:29:00 calendar indicating the date 28 November 1968
00:00:36:00 footage of a teenage girl sleeping, interspersed with footage of puppies, indicating she is dreaming
00:01:37:00 the newspaper boy arrives on a bicycle
00:02:15:00 sign ‘Victorian Animal Aid Trust’
00:02:31:00 girl patting puppies through a diamond wire fence
00:04:39:00 girl and puppy playing in the front yard of their house
00:04:51:00 giving the dog a bath in the laundry sink
00:06:00:00 having a nap in the sun together
00:06:11:00 title card ‘The End, Daddy DID buy me a Bow-Bow’

results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Len Moncur Home Movie Collection is a collection of amateur films made on 8mm film in the 1950s and 1960s. The collection includes a feature-length film of the 1956 Melbourne Olympics and four stop-motion animation titles: ‘The one-eyed monster’, ‘Storm at the 20th’, ‘One fine day’ and ‘It isn’t cricket’.

Len Moncur (1912–1997) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies and amimation films. With an interest in radio from a young age, he obtained his amateur transmitting licence in 1928, and served in the Air Force during WWII in radar service units. He purchased his first film camera in the USA in 1935, while on a trip visiting other radio and television experimenters, and began making home movies. He made an amaetur television set in 1950, which was shown at the All Models Exhibition, six years before the arrival of commerical television in Australia. In 1957, he joined the Melbourne 8mm Movie Club, where he regularly screened his home movies at film nights. Moncur’s 8mm stop-motion animation films won several amateur filmmaking awards in the 1960s.

This collection was donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s son Ken Moncur.

results.title: [Len Moncur Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
The Len Moncur Home Movie Collection is a collection of amateur films made on 8mm film in the 1950s and 1960s.

This animated film, titled ‘Storm at the 20th’, is a comedy about a group of beleaguered golf ball people, often wearing golf tee hats and with pipe cleaner limbs, who come together to protest against injury from golfers. They decide to take evasive action including using feathers to fly out of the way of golf sticks and a self-destructing do-it-yourself glider kit.

There are details such as the terrible injuries inflicted by golfers and one of the organisers drinking non-stop from what looks like a whiskey bottle.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:07:00 title cards ‘Storm at the 20th’ and ‘Animation by Len Moncur’
00:00:10:00 golf ball people are rushing around a busy street
00:00:18:00 a sign ‘Protest Meeting - Every Brand - Even repaints – Something must be done!’
00:00:26:00 sign ‘Trades Hall 20th Hole Branch’
00:00:29:00 wonderful miniature and detailed vehicles pass by including a tram from which many golf ball people alight
00:00:38:00 close-up of ‘Before it happens towing service’ tow truck
00:00:43:00 golf ball mechanics fix a broken down vehicle
00:00:50:00 an injured golf ball mechanic is taken away by stretcher and ambulance
00:01:16:00 the protest meeting proceeds with the manifesto stating that golf ball people are being treated badly by golfers
00:01:25:00 one of the organisers drinking strong spirits followed by several examples of gruesome golf ball injuries
00:02:35:00 baby golf ball people in a bassinette
00:02:48:00 the golf ball people learn evasive tactics on the golf course
00:04:33:00 boxes labelled ‘Do it yourself Glider Kit’ followed by a demonstration of how the glider assists the golf ball person avoid being hit by a golfer by flying through the air and then self-destructing once the golf ball person shields in a bush
00:05:09:00 the golf ball people squash into their sporty car and after travelling down the road, pop themselves into their boxes
00:05:24:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Nixon Family Home Movie Collection tells the story of a suburban family in 1960s–1980s Geelong, Victoria, with Mum (Dorothy) and Dad (Les) and the two kids, Karen and Stuart. Les and Dorothy lived at Herne Hill, Geelong, where the films show the two children growing up. Particularly Karen, from when she was a newborn baby up to her 21st birthday and first car.

Captured over ten movies, initially on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, most of the footage was taken by Les but occasionally when he appears on screen, we know Dorothy was behind the camera.

Through these family films we see the children grow up, the fun of beach holidays, fancy hats worn at family weddings, games played at birthdays and special holiday destinations. Some of the loveliest footage shows the simple pastimes of children: ‘dinking’ your baby brother around in the back of the tricycle at home, burying yourself up to the waist in the sand at the beach and jumping over a sprinkler on a hot day in the backyard by the ‘Hills Hoist’.

The large extended family also feature in the films and they would often holiday at their cousin’s beach house at 8th Avenue, Point Roadknight, on the Surf Coast of Victoria. In 1966, the family also spent some time in the sandy yard of a home in Alice Springs, from where they visit Amoonguna, an indigenous community 15kms southwest of Alice.

Visits from “Nana and Pop”, playing tennis, visiting a farm and family picnics also feature. Forget ‘lifestyles of the rich and famous’, this family collection spanning over twenty one years is far more enlightening and endearing.

This collection of home movies was donated to ACMI by Karen Corry.

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

Their children having grown up, this film captures Les and Dorothy enjoying a holiday in New Zealand.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Dorothy Nixon and two companions are part of a travel trip as indicated by their name tags
00:00:17:00 sign for ‘trial plots’ as part of a nursery in New Zealand, followed by Dorothy enjoying some views of public gardens
00:01:12:00 sign for ‘Cockayne Memorial Garden’ in honour of Dr Leonard Cockayne, a significant botanist in New Zealand
00:01:31:00 a conservatory in the gardens
00:02:00:00 a large lake amongst hills and a ship, a yacht and boats
00:02:13:00 views toward snowy covered mountains and looking down over a town from a higher vantage point followed by more snowy mountain tops
00:03:07:00 a tourist bus stopped at a roadside lookout point followed by more lakeside scenery
00:03:30:00 filming the mountains and landscape from inside a small plane
00:04:19:00 views of the motel accommodation for the travellers
00:05:10:00 sign for the ‘Omarama Motel Lodge’
00:05:34:00 a peacock, several small deer
00:06:01:00 sign ‘Welcome to Lake Manapouri’
00:06:20:00 a waterfall and tourists on a walk bridge over ‘Falls Creek’
00:06:45:00 filming from a bus as it travels through mountains
00:07:19:00 filming among fellow tourists in a boat on a river taking in the spectacular views of waterfalls and mountains
00:09:42:00 a steam train comes into view on a country track followed by views of houses and trees across a lake
00:10:18:00 looking at the front of a paddle steamer
00:10:40:00 filming from a sky lift as it travels up a hill followed by views over a town below
00:11:11:00 looking at the sky lift as it travels up
00:11:24:00 tourists walk over a bridge looking down at a fast moving creek or river
00:12:52:00 a helicopter landing
00:13:52:00 views of ‘Shantytown’, a tourist attraction on the South Island
00:14:41:00 on board a tourist boat on a lake
00;15:21:00 sign for ‘New Zealand Electricity’ after views of the plant
00:15:27:00 various ‘Wharenui’ (Maori meeting house) followed by views of hot springs
00:16:16:00 on a light plane travelling over a lake looking down on a seaplane
00:17:12:00 memorial to ‘Michael Joseph Savage 1872 – 1940’
00:17:20:00 traditional Maori dance performance
00:18:04:00 scenes of the rolling waves around the rocky coast
00:18:28:00 the travellers gather at the sign for ‘Tane Mahuta (Lord of the Forest)’, a very tall tree
00:18:30:00 the bus tour passengers, including Len and Dorothy, bid each other farewell, followed by travelling by taxi to the airport and ‘Quantas’ and ‘Air New Zealand’ planes at the terminals

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film captures a major event in the lives of the Nixon family – daughter Karen’s wedding. The fashion on the day is a wonderful example of the late 1980s and the bridesmaids wear Karen’s favourite colour, red. Karen’s new family, the Corrys, are in the film having visited from the UK.

Of interest in this film, when Karen arrives at the church there are many onlookers who are there but are not guests. At this period of time it was still customary, particularly in country areas, for members of the community to come along to watch the bridal party arrive and leave the church.

Later we see Karen preparing to leave for overseas possibly to Indonesia as we view a Garuda airplane from what appears to be the Observation Deck at Tullamarine Airport, Melbourne, when it was still open.

This film also contains scenes of a new kitten in the family, inside the house and in the yard chasing a rope hanging from the clothes line.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 Karen in a 1980s style wedding dress and her bridesmaids dressed in red, are relaxed for the camera in the family lounge room and outside on the terrace
00:01:15:00 the bridal party arrives at the church among a group of interested onlookers
00:01:24:00 father Les and daughter Karen pose for the camera alongside the bridal car
00:01:35:00 the bride and groom exchange rings inside the church (quite dark and grainy)
00:02:00:00 the bridal party pose for the camera, the men showing off some wonderful 1980s moustaches
00:02:42:00 the Nixon parents and the Corry parents gather with the bride and groom for a group photo
00:03:20:00 a family gathering in the backyard of the Geelong family home after the wedding
00:03:39:00 Dorothy, mother of the bride and always stylish, wearing a good example of a 1980s sundress in pink with black dots
00:04:16:00 having fun: a member of the family poses in a ‘Foster’s Lager’ singlet whilst drinking a ‘Foster’s Lager’ before then posing with a ‘beer gut’ shape for the camera
00:06:39:00 another family wedding where Karen is an attendant
00:07:22:00 a sign outside the church which states, ‘Do Not Drop Confetti’
00:09:35:00 Karen and her husband relaxed in front of the camera in the church grounds
00:12:40:00 a family gathering in the backyard
00:13:42:00 Karen packing for travel in front of a Christmas tree where a kitten is playing
00:14:23:00 a set Christmas table and then the family seated at the table except for Les who is filming
00:14:55:00 Karen checking in at the airport
00:15:54:00 airplanes on the tarmac being filmed from the rooftop Observation Deck at Melbourne Airport
00:19:50:00 after many scenes of playing, we see an exhausted kitten asleep in a cardboard box

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film contains family gatherings for birthdays and weddings as well as Christmas in 1979, a picnic in the Eastern Gardens in Geelong, a trip to Cairns and a tennis tournament in Launceston, Tasmania. results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film begins with Dorothy, Karen and Stuart relaxing around the family Christmas tree, 1984 and moves onto family activities in the backyard. There are two extended family weddings and some wonderful fashion from the early 1980s.

The highlight of the film is Karen’s 21st birthday where we see the traditional table for the presents to be displayed before Karen proudly poses for the camera in front of her new car.

Selected highlights list:

results.description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film begins with Dorothy, Karen and Stuart relaxing around the family Christmas tree, 1984 and moves onto family activities in the backyard. There are two extended family weddings and some wonderful fashion from the early 1980s.

The highlight of the film is Karen’s 21st birthday where we see the traditional table for the presents to be displayed before Karen proudly poses for the camera in front of her new car.

results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

This film features tennis tournaments in Geelong, Ballarat and Shepparton, as well as horse riding at a family farm and attending the extended family weddings in Bellbrae and Geelong. A highlight is Karen’s 13th birthday.
